newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine bonds supported by U.S. Treasuries.
newsitem.headline: Argentine bonds supported by U.S. Treasuries.

text.p: Argentine bonds rose early Thursday, helped once again by firmer U.S. Treasuries.
"The market is firm, there is some domestic demand," said a trader at an Argentine bank.
The dollar-denominated Bocon Previsional 2 due 2001 rose $0.50 to 120.80, while Argentina's FRB due 2005 advanced 1/4 to 85.
The trader added that activity was still fairly thin "with not much demand from abroad." But local pension funds were seen buying some peso-denominated bonds.
Financial consultancy IDEA said in an investor note "bocones in pesos are preferred as they benefit from modest tighter dollar-peso spread and their quasi fixed rate status."
The peso-denominated Bocon Proveedor 1 due 2007 rose 10 centavos to 93.05.

Separately, the lower house of Congress gave general approval late Wednesday to the government's 1997 budget proposal which includes a deficit of $3.2 billion and anticipates five percent gross domestic product growth.
